title: 114_hr5405
content: The "SOAR to Health and Wellness Act of 2016" defines human trafficking and establishes a pilot program. The Secretary will establish a pilot program called "SOAR to Health and Wellness Training" to train healthcare providers on identifying and assisting human trafficking victims in compliance with legal requirements. The pilot program "SOAR to Health and Wellness Training" aims to train healthcare providers on identifying and assisting human trafficking victims by implementing proper protocols, providing coordinated and victim-centered care, and considering integration with existing training programs for victims of domestic violence and other forms of abuse. The pilot program established aims to address domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, stalking, child abuse, neglect, maltreatment, and sexual exploitation. It includes functions from the Stop, Observe, Ask, and Respond to Health and Wellness Training program and engaging stakeholders to develop a flexible training module. The pilot program aims to address various forms of abuse and exploitation. It includes developing a flexible training module that adapts to changing needs and providing grants for training in diverse healthcare settings. Technical assistance is also offered for nationwide health education programs. The pilot program aims to address abuse and exploitation by developing training materials for healthcare settings, incentivizing their use, and collecting data on human trafficking victims. The program will terminate on October 1, 2022. The pilot program aims to address abuse and exploitation in healthcare settings by developing training materials, incentivizing their use, and collecting data on human trafficking victims. SEC. 4 outlines data collection and reporting requirements. During fiscal years 2018 through 2022, the Secretary will collect data on facilities and providers involved in the pilot program addressing abuse and exploitation in healthcare settings. This data includes the total number of facilities operating under the program and the number of trained healthcare providers. Additionally, an initial report will include this data for submission under subsection (b). The Secretary will collect data on facilities and providers involved in the pilot program addressing abuse and exploitation in healthcare settings. This includes the total number of facilities operating under the program and the number of trained healthcare providers. A report must be submitted to Congress within 90 days after the start of each fiscal year from 2018 to 2022. Authorization of appropriations for this Act is set at $3,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2018 to 2022.
